titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p:
Dr. Woodward was here this morning and recommended a new modification of my daily Medicines Hucsams Tincture to be taken twice a day and also when I could find it convenient to take Galvanic attacks, but no medicine has much effect upon me. Edmund Chadwick A.M. came to solicit contributions for Starkey Seminary Yates County. New York. I gave him a copy
of my Letters on Free Masonry not for the Starkey Seminary but for himself— I took my daily ride before dinner with Mrs. Charles her Mary and Miss Cutts I dined at my Sons up the hill and walked round the long Square at sunset— My Wife, Mrs. John, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa, with my son and his daughter Louisa Catherine all went to Boston to see the Italian Opera Corrado Altamura at the Howard street Theatre They got home just before midnight— Mrs. C. F. Adams came and spent the Evening with me till nine oclock and read to me a long story about Mr. Peabody and my Aunt his wife— Elizabeth. C. Adams and Isaac. Hull. spent the Evening with us.

A fine night and frosty morning, but I was more indisposed than I have been for some time— I received a Letter from John. S. H Fogg dated South Berwick Maine, who requests for a literary Institution an Autograph of my Father and of any other of the other Presidents of the United States— I received a printed Circular Invitation from Elias G. Drake Hamilton Fish Wm. Hall Joseph C. Hart and Calvin Pollard Committee of Arrangements of the Washington Monument association of the City of New York to attend at the laying of the Corner stone of the Monument on the 19th. of the present month of October anniversary of the Surrender of Cornwallis 19th. October 1781. with a request for an early answer Sunset ride with Mrs. John Adams, Mrs. Charles, and Miss Cutts round the Braintree Depot— My Son with his wife and daughter Louisa were here in the Evening.

An uneasy comfortless night Mr. Lunt administered the Communion and preached from Luke 13.23— “Then said one unto Him Lord are there few that be saved and He said unto them. 24. Strive to enter in at the straight gate for many I say unto you will seek to enter in and shall not be able”— It is remarkable that a direct answer to the question is evaded instead of it is an implied censure upon the question itself and a strong exhortation to the hearers instead of busying themselves with inquiries as to the number of those that should be saved to confine their attention to the means of securing their own Salvation. The Discourse was elaborate and impressive— That of the afternoon was by Mr. Simmons from Matthew 11.11. [“]Verily I say unto you among them that are born of women there hath not risen a greater than John the Baptist, notwithstanding he that is least in the Kingdom of Heaven is greater than he”—an interesting Discourse upon the character of John the Baptist. There is a German Essayist by the name of Fuster who in a Review of the Gallery of Pictures at Dresden has selected an imaginary Portrait of John the Baptist, as the subject of a dissertation upon the character of this wonderful personage, which I think Mr. Simmons must have read, and from which he must have borrowed many ideas in portraying this forerunner of the Messiah, deserving of the profound meditation of every pious Christian. Mr. Loring of Hingham was at the afternoon service and paid me afterwards a visit. Mrs. Loring being at Mr. John Greenleafs— Mr. Quincy was here in the Evening, and proposed to take some fair day to visit the Observatory at Cambridge to make up our failure to attend with the Committee of the Board of Overseers on the 21st. of September My son and his wife were also here this Evening. Fine day. I walked to and from meeting this morng—

A cheerless and uncomfortable night. My Wife Mrs. John Adams, Miss Cutts and Mary Louisa, went to Boston this morning and returned to dine. Miss Cutts had intended to leave us and go for Washington this day with the Trist family, who left Boston this afternoon but she was disappointed— Col Bomford was here to accompany her but she was equally disappointed in not being able to go with him. I was out upon my morning walk when he was here and did not see him. Miss Elizabeth Susan Quincy, and Miss Abby Quincy, were also here and I requested them to propose to their Father to go on an expedition to visit the Observatory next Thursday if the weather shall permit— I received in the Evening a note from Miss Quincy accepting this proposition of which Mr. Quincy engages to give notice to President Edward Everett. In addition to my reading of Dupuis Universelle Religion, through the slow length of which I am continuing to drag. I have this day undertaken to read Lord Brougham translation of the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown. The time of the daily passage of the Railway Cars between Boston and Quincy was this day changed and instead of arriving at a quarter before three P.M. it now comes at a quarter past four, so that when we called for Mrs. Charles at half past four she was at dinner and did not go with us— Miss Louisa. C. Smith and Miss Cutts rode with me to Milton returning by the Neponset Turnpike— My Son and his wife were here in the Evening and also our neighbours Mr. and Mrs. Emmons— The accounts were received this day of the taking of the City of Mexico by General Scott on the 17th. of September.

I had a more quiet and comfortable night than for several preceeding days. We have had several frosty mornings and the weather continues fair— I took a ride before dinner with Mr. Dehone of New York, and Mrs. Charles Adams, to the Quarries, where we alighted and surveyed the work— I dined with Mr. Dehone at my sons house At five oclock Mr. Dehone returned to Boston by the Railway— In the Evening my Son and his wife were here.

Walk round the long Square before dinner, met and walked with Price Greenleaf— Received five printed Tracts on Poverty, Prosperity and Religion united. Letter from Henry Gassett enclosing one from Benjamin Ferris Bonair Hartford Md. 9. month 25. 1847. to him. Mr. Ferris wants to get a present of a book to me, which requires an answer from me to Mr. Gassett, but I had not time to have written it to day— Miss Cutts left us this day and went to Boston and from thence by the Fall River Railway to return to Washington. Mr. Robinson the Episcopal Clergyman who was some time settled here visited me this Day and told me he was happily settled in a Seamens Church at Boston— Mr.came with Mr. Robinson, and I gave him at his request an Autograph.

I had a very indifferent nights rest and scarcely expect any other. I nevertheless rose this morning, rather earlier than is my custom now. Breakfasted, and at eight oclock this morning, called in my
Carriage at Mr. Josiah Quincys and took him with me to visit the Observatory at Cambridge, the other Members of the Committee of the Board of Overseers, namely David Sears, Abbott Lawrence J. Ingersoll Bowditch and Francis Peabody did pay the visit on the 21st. of September and made a Report thereof to be returned with Reports from the Perkins Professor of Astronomy and Mathematics Mr. Pierce and from Wm. C. Bond, the Observator to be returned to the Board of Overseers during the approaching Winter Session of the General Court. In consequence of my own personal indisposition, of that of President Quincy suffering from inflammation of the eyes, of President Everett who was that day confined to his Bed by sickness and of a threatened storm in the morning, I was deterred from calling upon Mr. Quincy to proceed to Cambridge on that day as we had agreed. We were disappointed accordingly in attending with the other Members of the Committee and substituted a visit of this day, for our own satisfaction— We reached Cambridge at ten oclock and President Everett went with us to the Observatory, where we found the Observator William. Cranch. Bond. and his son and Assistant George. C. Bond—but Professor Pierce was not there. The great Frauenhofer Refractor a small Transit Instrument and a very complete Comet seeker were all there perfectly mounted. The large Equatorial upon a very Capital stone pier. There is however one large Transit Instrument to be constructed by Simms at London which has not yet arrived and seems to have been too long delayed. one of the Glasses having disappointed the Maker himself so that he concluded to make another. The sky though clear early this morning had clouded up before we reached the Observatory, and we could take no view through the principal Instrument About twelve oclock we returned to President Everetts and then home. I left Mr. Quincy at his house and reached my own before three
oclock in time for dinner— In the Afternoon I took a solitary walk, and my Son and his Wife were here in the Evening— Elizabeth Adams and Isaac Hull were also here— In our ride this morning, I had a conversation with Mr. Quincy in which, I suggested to him the expediency, of preparing a plan for organizing the Observatory with reference to its two distinct objects, first, as an Astronomical Observatory, for the assiduous cultivation of the Science of Astronomy, and Secondly, as a Branch of the Institution for Education of the youths of this Commonwealth— I thought it required a two fold organization having reference to both its objects one being the cultivation of the Science and the other the instruction of the Students at the University. Mr. Quincy concurred with me, in this view, and I intended to have conversed with the President, and him together, but we had not time sufficient for it— I spoke of it to Mr. Everett, but the difficulty immediately occurred to him of the want of Funds. He said the University had already incurred an expense of thirty two thousand dollars in addition to the donations which had been applied to this object, and that no provision had yet been made for the support of an Observator. There is yet much to be done and little encouragement before this Institution can be made to answer its complicated purposes—

I had a more comfortable night, but the day threatened a storm. Mr. Emmons called here, with two Volumes of Rogers Poems, which he proposes to present to Mr.Meredith, and he requested me to write some lines, but without saying what by way of autograph. I wrote accordingly a very few lines expressing my opinion of Rogers, as the most pleasing English Poet of the present Century. I remember reading the Pleasures of Memory at the time of its first publication. I think as early as
1793. and they gave me more pleasure than any of the Poems of Cowper, Burns, in any of the De la cruscan writers of the same period, and much more than Southey or Peter Pindar at that time more popular than all the rest, and now almost totally forgotten. I was personally acquainted with Mr. Rogers at that time and met him several times in Society though not at his own house— Campbell was of rather a later date, Walter Scott still later. Byron and Shelley last of all. Coleridge and Wordsworth are hardly to be included in the Catalogue and of some later Poet Tasters I cannot charge my memory with their names. I ask the pardon of Mr. Moore upon the whole the one who will last the longest of them all with filmy, gauzy, glossamary lines. as Darwin was characterized by the author of the once famous Pursuits of Literature. I took a ride with my Wife and Mrs. Charles

I walked yesterday morning to the Quincy Stone Bank. to deposit there a check for one hundred dollars given me by my son and to draw for two hundred, one for my wife, and one for Mrs. John for our current household expenses but though in banking hours I found the door locked and a paper pasted on it that the Cashier was gone to Boston but would be back at twelve oclock—a poor sample of Bank punctuality— I returned again this day and found the Cashier Bartlett at the Counter. I deposited the Check given me by my son, and drew one hundred dollars in Bills of the Bank, which I gave to Mrs. John, for the household expenses, and another of one hundred dollars which I paid in gold to my Wife, being the Sum which I borrowed of her last Summer, when we came from Washington— I walked before dinner round the Railway Square and after dinner—with Mrs. John and Mrs. Charles, I took Miss Sampson to her home at Braintree— I wrote the lines in the Vol of Rogers Poems to my great annoyance. I am almost entirely physically disabled from writing, and find it an insupportable task to be called upon for an autograph.

Revd. John H. Morison preached by exchange with Mr. Lunt. His morning text was from Hebrews 12.1. “Wherefore seeing we also are compassed about with so great a cloud of witnesses let us lay aside every weight and the sin which doth so easily beset us, and let us run with patience the race that is set before us.” From some of his preliminary remarks I expected that he was about to give us a funeral Discourse, but it did not appear to have reference to the decease of any individual, but considered all the persons with whom we had been acquainted who have gone to the World of Spirits as constituting this cloud of witnesses. Mr. Morison dined with us, and the text of his afternoon Discourse was from John 4.32. “But he said unto them I have meat to eat, that ye know not of.” I walked to and from Meeting morning and Afternoon and with more power to walk than I have had for some months. Mr. Beale with his two daughters spent part of the Evening with us—as did also my son and his wife.

We had no visitors this day— I walked round the Long Railway Square before dinner— Rode to Braintree with Mrs. John, and Mrs. Charles. F. Adams— I have received a Letter from Robert E. H. Lovering dated September 2nd. 1847. Lancaster Ohio post marked October 3d., enclosing several newspaper slips of Mr. Loverings Poetry. I gave him some years since a Letter of introduction to Col Aspinwall the Consul of the United States at London—he says, it aided him materially, in prosecuting his Antiquarian researches at the British Museum, that he has now sundry manuscripts arranged in publishable order, but that his funds are exhausted by his trip to Europe and he cannot publish them in a Volume. He wants one hundred dollars to aid him in this purpose
and send it to him as soon as possible by the Mail which he will return at the proper time. He proposes also to aid me, in writing and to borrow money also for that purpose— I answered his Letter declining all his proposals. My son and his wife were here in the Evening

A fine day. My wife, with Mrs. Charles Adams and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa, went to Boston and returned to dine— I walked round the long Railway Square before dinner but lost my afternoon ride— I recd a Letter from Ezekiel Bacon Utica New York the 8th. October 1847 about the leading Article of the Democratic Review of this month of October. My son was here this Evening without his wife.

A stormy night, sleepless, hopeless. Received a Letter from President Edward Everett with copies of two Reports to him from the Director of the Observatory William C. Bond one of the 26th. July, and the other of 22d. September 1847. Lieut Joseph H. Adams, was here this morning and went before dinner to Charlestown where he is stationed. The weather all the morning was so showery that I could not go out. Received a Letter from John Russell Bartlett New York 6. Octr. 1847. with a pamphlet by him on the Progress of Ethnology—which he has read to the New York Historical Society—received a Pamphlet Proceedings of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences, containing Professor Pierce notice of Mr. Sears. C. Walkers discovery that the Planet Neptune was observed as a Fixed Star on the 10th. of May 1795. from which Prof Pierce infers, that the Planet Neptune though predicted by Leverrier was not the Planet which he predicted but another which ought not to have been found where he foretold it would be
which is much like Moliere’swho upon being told that the heart is on the right side and the Liver is on the left says “nous avons changé toute cela.[”] Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and her daughter Mary. Left Mary Louisa to pass the night with Elizabeth. C. Adams— my son here alone in the Eveg

No Supper last night— Slept this morning till daylight. Received a Letter from W. J. Mc.Cormick formerly Postmaster to the House of Representatives of the United States, dismissed by the Democratic House in 1843. and now again a Candidate for election to that Office. Walk round the long Railway Square. Reading Dupuis on the Eleusinian mysteries and all the Ancient initiations including those of the Christian Religion. Ride round Milton Hill with my wife, Mrs. Charles and Mary. My son and his wife here this Evening—

After a fortunate day, had but half a nights sleep Andrews the fishmonger here this morning, I took a Rock Cod— Reading Lord Brougham’s Translation of the Oration of Demosthenes for the Crown, which I find about as hard to understand as the Original— I received the Protestant Quarterly Review for October 1847. and an account of a Taylor Meeting in Scott County Ky, no date General Zachary Taylor nominated for President of the United States. Walk round the long Railway Square. Mrs. Beck from Charlestown was here—she has a Petition before Congress for a Pension for her deceased mother which was rejected Winter before last and which she desires to have renewed at the approaching Session of Congress— She applies also for charity and told me she meant to apply to Col Perkins.
visit from Mrs. Josiah Quincy and Miss Abby Quincy. they move to Boston for the Winter next Monday— Afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and little Mary on the road to Squantum by the spot where Mr. Appleton is about to build a house.

Quiet and comfortable night. Frosty and beautiful morning My wife went with Mary Louisa to Boston. One returned to dinner, the other after dinner Morning visits from the Rev Mr. Loring from the State of Maine and from the Revd. Mr. Harding of the Railway Village Church Milton. Meridian walk across the Lane round the Long Railway Square— I met lying on the side of the lane on this side of my sons house Joshua Yeamans with papers a claimant for a Pension for services in the last War with Great Britain. he showed me one of his Papers a Certificate from his Captain Samuel Hough— I told him he must take his Papers to Washington and I would aid if it should be in my power. Received a Letter from Mr. Frye Washington 12th. Oct. 1847. Columbia Mills damaged by a great flood— I rode after dinner with Mrs. Charles and her Mary to Braintree and we took Miss Sampson home. My son and his wife were here till nine oclock.

A quiet night and beautiful October day Mr. Lunt preached this morning from Mark 12.42.43. [“]And there came a certain poor widow, and she threw in two mites, which make a farthing— 43. And he called unto him his disciples and saith unto them, Verily I say unto you, That this poor widow hath cast
more in than they all they which have cast into the treasury”—and in the Afternoon from Revelation 5.6. “And I beheld, and lo, in the midst of the throne and of the four beasts, and in the midst of the elders, stood a Lamb, as it had been slain, having seven horns and seven eyes, which are the seven Spirits of God sent forth into all the earth.” Evening visit from Mr. Josiah Quincy and my son was here till the ringing of the Bell— I walked to and from Meeting Morning and Afternoon.

lg.l: Nor think though men were none
That Heaven would want spectators, God want praise
Millions of Spiritual creatures walk the earth
Unseen both when we wake and when we sleep
All these with ceaseless praise His works behold
Both day and night; How often from the steep
Of echoing hill or thicket, have we heard
Celestial voices to the midnight air.
(Soul all responsive each to other note)
Singing their great Creator? oft in bands
While they keep watch or nightly rounding walk
With heavenly touch of instrumental sounds
In full harmonic number joined their songs
Divide the night and lift her thoughts to Heaven

div.p: Paradise Lost 4. 675.

This is said by Adam to Eve in conversation, it does not absolutely appear that it expresses Miltons opinion of man in his fallen state but it contains the avowed belief of Emanuel Swedenborg and of his Sectarians. That communion with Spiritual Beings may have been one of the enjoyments of Adam in Paradise, I have right to deny though it would seem that it was not enjoyed at least with equal clearness by Eve. He asserts the fact as a thing not before known to her and yet he reminds her that they have heard these Celestial voices from the “steep of echoing hill or thicket, singing their great Creator”— However it may have been with Adam. I believe it was but a delusive dream in
in Swedenborg. the existence of intelligent Spiritual Beings I cannot deny nor affirm—as a part of the Christian Religion it is a subject of belief, but not of proof and of the present state of the world— I never have heard “Celestial voices Singing to the midnight air” nor do I believe that any other human being in possession of his senses has heard them. These lines however gave occasion to much reflection in my mind this day. My Grandaughter Mary Louisa went with Mrs. Miller and Mrs. George T. Bigelow to Charlestown to visit Lieut Joseph. H. Adams in charge of the Ship Franklin— They returned this Afternoon— I took my morng walk and afternoon ride with my wife Mrs. Charles and her Mary round Milton Hill— Charles daughter Louisa dined with us— I received from Aaron. H. Palmer six copies of a Prospectus of the Unknown Countries of the East, i.e. the principal Countries of Eastern Africa and Asia— Also a Letter from Joseph Henry Secretary of the Smithsonian Institution dated Princeton 13th. October 1847. and enclosing a printed Paper of general considerations which should serve as a guide in adopting a plan of organization I suppose the Institution is already Organized by an Act of Congress under which this Mr. Joseph Henry has been appointed the Secretary—but he has a different plan of organization which is evidently sliding into a job— My son and his wife were here in the Evening— I received also from Revd. Mr. Clarke rector of Christ Church Quincy to which paper I subscribed some time since for five dollars which I now paid.

Anniversary of the Surrender of Cornwallis at Yorktown At New York the day celebrated by laying the Corner Stone of a monument to the memory of George Washington. The Corner Stone was laid by the Governor of the State Young
and Addresses were made by the Chief Justice Jones and Col J. C. Hart— There was an Exhibition at the University of Cambridge. My Granddaughter went with Mrs. Miller and Mrs. George T. Bigelow and came home late this Evening. My Wife dined and drank Tea at my Sons up the hill. We took a ride towards Evening. The Steamer Cambria arrived at Boston this morning. Alexander. H. Everett died at Canton in China the 29th. of last June. Peace to his remains. I introduced him to Public life and had a very high opinion of his talents, from which I once formed great expectations, they have ended in sad disappointment. He died in a somewhat eminent Public Office, though not with the character of independent spirit which I once hoped for him.

Awake long before daylight I walked up the Hill and spoke with my son before he went to Boston. I wrote to R. G. Metcalf Representative of the Town of Wrentham in the State Legislature asking information of him to enable me to answer a Letter which I have received from W. J. Brown 2d. Assistant Postmaster General asking advice for the location of the Post Office at West Wrentham Elizabeth. C. Adams, Isaac Hull Adams, and Lieut Joseph. H. Adams. dined with us— Elizabeth rode with us after dinner round Milton Hill returning by the Neponset Bridge Turnpike. While we were out Mr. Joseph Russell of Boston paid us a visit. we did not see him— A Mr. Ewer a member of the Massachusetts Historical and Genealogical Society was also here— I gave him a printed Engraving byof Stuarts last Portrait of my Father, also an Engraved Profile of General Washington given me by Christopher Hughes. My son and his wife passed the Evening here. and Elizabeth took leave of us going tomorrow with her Uncle Joseph Harrod for N. Orleans—

A nearly sleepless and much distressed night Mary Louisa went this morning to the Railway Depot and saw the departure of Elizabeth C. Adams for New Orleans. Dr. William. B. Duggan and Capt Charles Swift were here. Captain Swift is a Candidate for the appointment of Light House Keeper of a new Light House to be erected on Minotts Ledge of the Cohasset Rocks or of any other Light House within the Commonwealth of Massachusetts— His application is already made to the Secretary of the Treasury with a numerously signed recommendation in his favor. he requested also mine. I received a Letter from Matthew Saint Clair Clarke with a Circular announcing himself as a Candidate for the Office of Clerk of the House of Representatives of the United States for the 30th. Congress— But the Clerk of the last Congress B. B. French is a very excellent Officer and in making application took time by the forelock in advance of Mr. Clarke— I walked round the long Railway Square before dinner but scarcely able to drag one leg before the other. Evening ride

I had a comparitively quiet night and slept till nearly daylight. I began a Letter to President Edward Everet to send with the Report of the Committee of the Board of Overseers on the Observatory but I was not able to finish it. Dr. Woodward was here this fore noon with a Galvanic Battery the effect of which he proposes to try upon my complaint— He gave me a very slight shock which appeared to me to produce little or no effect— I rode this afternoon from four till dark. Isaac Hull Adams was here this Evening. And my son with his wife.

There was rain great part of the night, which cleared off this morning I had a night of tolerable repose but in walking this morng after the rain had ceased found myself weaker than I have yet been, and was unable to extend my walk more than round the short Railway Square. The dampness of the atmosphere affects me most unfavorably. I received a note from the Revd. Matthew Hale Smith with a small Volume containing the four Sermons addressed to young persons and delivered in Washington in April 1846. Immediately before he left the 2nd. Presbyterian Church. Prefixed to the Volume is a note with a fac-simile of the resolution of the Congregation of the 2nd. Presbyterian Church adopted at my Motion on the 10th. May 1846. and the Title page announces this, as the fifth Edition of the work. It has also my Letter to him of the 7th. May 1846. Mr. Matthew Hale Smith is now the minister of a Congregational Society in Boston—and has become involved in a controversy with Mr. Mann the Secretary School Commission.

A young man from the Divinity School Cambridge named Capin preached for Mr. Lunt this morning from Acts 1.8—on the gift of Tongues conferred upon the Apostles on the day of Pentecost by the Holy Ghost—and this afternoon from James 4.14. Lieut Joseph Adams came from Charlestown and dined with us, but returned this Afternoon to his Ship the Franklin— My son spent the Evening here. his daughter Louisa Catherine has been much indisposed for the last ten days and is yet confined at home— Our Mary Louisa is afflicted with a Whitlow. I walked to and from Meeting morning and Afternoon—but my power of locomotion continues gradually to decay—

This is the day ever memorable to me the anniversary of my Fathers marriage on the 25th. October 1764. A day of happy memory but now introduced by a hapless half sleepless night succeeded by a cloudy day of variable weather alternate sunshine and shower and blowing the sirocco South west wind— I walked up the hill round the short Railway Square barely able to stand on my feet. I was called down to Old man named William Hunt a mendicant I received a Letter from William Clarkson Johnson son of my deceased brother Charles daughter the first wife of Alexander B. Johnson of Utica New York, informing me that he intends to be married during the first of next month to Miss Harriet Douw of Albany and immediately afterwards to embark for Europe to pass there the ensuing Winter and to return home to resume his business next Spring— I am still occupied upon a Letter to President Edward Everett.

Morning visit from Ex President Quincy whom I agreed to meet, if possible at the Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society at Boston next Thursday—when I propose to communicate to him my Letter to President Edward Everett which I have not yet finished. My Son gave me a note for a thousand dollars from him to me for ninety days to be endorsed by me— Dr. Woodward was here and gave me a slight shock of the Galvanic Battery. which I shall take without any confidence in its efficacy or in my own power of using it. Afternoon ride to the Squantum road. I received from Mr. Charles
Ewer the first three numbers of the New England Historical and Gennealogical Register published under the direction of the New England Historic Genealogical Society by the Revd. Wm. Cogswell D.D. Editor. Also Robert Cushman’s sermon on the Sin and Danger of Self-love, delivered at Plymouth in New England in December 1621.

Change in the night from the Southwest Summer to the North west Winter wind and Fahrenheit’s Thermometer this morning at Sunrise at 16. to me a half sleepless night Morning walk round the Long Railway Square and an afternoon ride with my wife and my Granddaughter Mary Louisa to Braintree, and round by Quincy Point. I received a Letter from Arnold Buffum New York 25th. October 1847. with a printed Circular convoking a World’s Convention to be held at New York to which convocation he requests my signature and my consent to preside at the Convention. which I must of course decline. I received also a printed Circular in behalf of the Farming Colored Association dated Northern Star Office Albany 18th. October 1847— This is a project for removing the Colored population to the new Western States— I received also a Letter from Caleb Mills Professor of Greek Wabash College Iowa Post marked Crawfordsville and requesting my opinion respecting the intention in appropriating every 36th. section of Land in the new States to Educational purposes. From which it appears that the State of Michigan differs on the Construction of this Law with the States of Ohio, and Indiana. and with it, the first number of a Periodical Journal entitled The Compact No 1. 16th. Octr. 1847. J. B. Jones Editor and Proprieter. the first Article of which relates to the preservation of the Union All these Papers are symptoms of the firmentation of Slavery in this Country. My son and his wife were here in the Eveg.

Another cold night— Thermometer said to have been in Boston as low as 12. Almost unexampled and I suffer with cold accordingly, but I nevertheless went with my wife and Louisa Catherine to Boston and attended the monthly meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society. It was half past twelve before I reached the Society’s apartment where about thirty members were present and the President was reading a Manuscript Letter to him from a gentleman in England containing numerous anecdotes concerning many individuals of the emigrations succeeding that of Governor Winthrop in 1632. and 1634. I heard only a part of this paper which prolonged the Session of this day till it was past two oclock— Among the Members present were Ex President Josiah Quincy and Mr. Robert. C. Winthrop recently returned from a voyage to England. I gave to Mr. Quincy the Report of the Committee of the Overseers of Harvard University on the Observatory with the annexed papers and my own Letter to President Edward Everett all to be reported to the Overseers at the next Winter Session of the Legislature— Mr. Quincy engaged to deliver or transmit them all to President Edward Everett. At the adjournment of the Meeting I walked to Dr. Frothingham’s house where I found my wife already in the Carriage at the door and returned home to Quincy to dinner. The cold of the night, had subsided but not so as to give me a comfortable Evening. Isaac Hull and Lieut. Joseph. H. Adams dined with us. and the former staid with us for the night. I had hoped to derive benefit from the exercise of the ride and the walk in Boston, but was disappointed and found myself quite unwell this night.

A wretched night and hopeless day— The weather continues unceasingly cold— I had visits from the Revd. Mr. Lunt, Mr. Josiah Brigham, & professionally from Dr. Woodward who gave me a shock of half an hour of the Galvanic Battery, from which I expect no relief. Mr. Lunt gave me a Manuscript heretofore Copied, by his Father of a Memoir of Mr. Shackford which Mr. Daniel Webster had communicated to the Late Judge John Davis. Mr. Brigham’s visit was to take leave of us in the expectation of our departing for Washington next Monday which God grant we may have power to do—

My son with his family moved to Boston for the Winter. I walked round the Railway Square but had no afternoon ride. Afternoon visit from Joseph Russell of Boston and also from Mr. Minott Thayer of Braintree. My condition remains as it has been for months

Mr. Capin a student at the Divinity School Cambridge preached for Mr. Lunt who was himself in the Pulpit, was from Acts 1.8. [“]But ye shall receive power after that the Holy Ghost is come upon you and ye shall be witnesses unto me both in Jerusalem and in all Judea and in Samaria and unto the uttermost parts of the earth.” and the Discourse was upon what is
called the gift of tongues on the day of Pentecost conferred upon the Apostles—a subject which I think ought not to be discussed by any youthful Student at a Divinity School. Mr. Capin did not appear to have any settled opinion what this gift of Tongues was. he seemed to question whether it was a miraculous power to speak different languages. although that has been generally held to be the power precisely conferred. I cannot conceive indeed how the account in the Book of the Acts can be otherwise understood it says “When the day of Pentecost was fully come they were all with one accord in one place and suddenly there came a sound from Heaven as of a rushing mighty wind and it filled all the house where they were sitting and there appeared unto them cloven tongues like as of fire and it sat upon each of them and they were all filled with the Holy Ghost and began to speak with other tongues as the Spirit gave them utterance and there were dwelling at Jerusalem Jews, devout men out of every nation under Heaven now when this was noised abroad the multitude came together and were confounded because that every man heard them speak in their own language, and they were all amazed and marvelled saying one to another, behold are not all these which speak Gallalaeans and how hear we every man in our own tongue wherein we were born Parthians, and Medes, and Elamites and the dwellers in Mesopotamia and in Judea and Cappadocia, in Pontus and Asia Frigia and Pamphilia, in Egypt and in the parts of Lybia about Cyrene and strangers of Rome, Jews and proselytes. Cretes and Arabians we do hear them speak in our tongues the wonderful works of God. And they were all amazed and were in doubt saying one to another what meaneth this.” Nothing can be more explicit though to be sure others mocking said these men are full of new wine. Mr. Capin
